title: New Mechanic: Temporary Damage
body:
What if you could inflict a sort of 'negative shield' onto your opponent? Temporary damage that would restore health back to your opponent after a certain time, but would still be completely lethal if your enemy ever drops below zero.

This would allow for some interesting spells, such as a balanced high damage finisher - that can really only be used as a finisher.

A couple edits:

1.  It wouldn't have to be a skill with 100% 'grey damage', it could do part temporary and part real. 

2. Another option (that I like a lot better) is a champion who after a basic combo could choose between: 
(a) A high damage finisher that does a bunch more 'grey damage'
(b) A low damage trading option that 'procs' the temporary damage to make it stick. 

I appreciate all the feedback!

Executes (Darius, Garen, Riven, etc...) can be used when the target is at full health, even if they're more effective at lower health. I think this is a great idea. 

If you want to execute someone, go ahead. If your team is going after an enemy, and you're almost dead, you don't want to stick around, but the "damage" would be enough for your team to get the kill before the time is up

It might even cause the enemy to start running back to turret (because they think they'll die) allowing for free aa's ad other spells, so when they heal back up from your -shield, they still have to back.

All in all, this could be used in a lot of great ways.

Darius' ult has an execute mechanic, it isnt tied to being an execute.

Garen's ult has a base damage and scales on missing health.

Riven's ult has increased range and massive damage boost tied to it.

Notice something about these 3 skills? They are all ultimates. Meaning the fight is going all out and going to probably be decided one way or anything. So the execute portion is useful.

But what OP is describe is also damage that doesnt stick. That doesnt feel good for anyone to use. And making a champion feel good to play is half of the challenge of the design.

Like you could have a base damage, and extra damage done like this. There's still some use for the ability outside of it being an execute, but it's not only useful for an execute.

It's nearly the same idea as other execute skills; the entire concept of an execute is to make them useless when your victim is full health. This mechanic simply gives a way to specify a skill as an execute, and to balance the skill so that it doesn't get abused. It would also have potential to delay engages, to bait heals, and other interesting things. 

A skill that does a lot of damage straight up is just too powerful, that's why the current executes mainly do a percentage of lost HP. It is true, most executes are very situational, but there are many highly effective, yet situational skills; just as there are many less potent, but generally more useful ones. This is the heart of diversity, and diversity is at the core of any strategic game. It is part of what makes League fun.

I've actually tinkered with this idea on a concept or two. Generally....

* Seems to work better as a support-skill than a part of a nuker/DoT kit. 
* It has to be true damage, otherwise it's next-to-useless.
* It works best as a small amount of "extra" damage. A debuff/curse. (10/20/30/40/50 true damage per auto, for example)
* The way it works with grievous wounds makes or breaks this ability. If it works, it's dangerous. If it doesn't, I'd guess balanced?

I imagine this would be most useful on a kit that prioritizes disengage rather than using it as an execute. A debuff that you have to get away from or risk dying while it's on. Alternatively, fighting through the pain and surviving as your HP comes back.
